commander.name: Orlando Ward
commander.previous_service: Commandant of the Tank School, Fort Knox

M3 Lee.notes: 75mm gun in hull sponson, 37mm gun in turret. Used by 13th Armored Regiment

M3 Grant.notes: British turret variant with radio. Some received from British stocks

M4 Sherman.notes: 75mm gun. One regiment's worth transferred to British for El Alamein

M3 Stuart.notes: 37mm gun. Equipped light tank battalions of both armored regiments

M5 Stuart.notes: 37mm gun. Beginning to replace M3 Stuarts

M2 Halftrack.role: Armored personnel carrier for armored infantry

M7 Priest 105mm SPG.notes: Self-propelled howitzer on M3 chassis. Three battalions (18 each)

M3 37mm Anti-Tank Gun.notes: Towed anti-tank gun, being phased out

M45 Quadmount .50 cal.notes: Four .50 cal M2 machine guns on halftrack mount

supply_logistics.supply_status: Strained but adequate for initial operations. Primary constraints: long supply lines from Oran (800km to Tunisia front), limited port capacity at Oran, inadequate forward storage facilities, and inexperienced logistics staff. Fuel and ammunition prioritized over spare parts and maintenance supplies. Combat Command B experienced significant equipment losses at Medjez el Bab (10-11 December) due to mud and hasty withdrawal.

weather_environment.terrain_type: mixed terrain - coastal plains near Oran transitioning to hilly interior and mountain passes approaching Tunisia

subordinate_units.notes: Three tank battalions: 1st Bn (light tanks), 2nd Bn (medium tanks), 3rd Bn (medium tanks)
Three tank battalions. 1st and 2nd Battalions part of Combat Command B at Oran landing
M8 Greyhound armored cars, M3 scout cars, light tanks
Flexible combined arms task force. Composition varied by mission
Landed at Oran 8 November. Suffered losses at Medjez el Bab 10-11 December
Maintenance, supply, medical, and administrative units

tactical_doctrine.role: Armored exploitation and breakthrough force. Heavy armored division optimized for sustained mobile operations with emphasis on tank firepower and shock action.
special_capabilities: Three-battalion armored regiments provide greater striking power than light armored divisions
Combat Command structure allows flexible combined arms task organization
Self-propelled artillery maintains pace with armored advance
Mechanized infantry provides immediate infantry support without dismounting
tactical_innovations: Combat Command system pioneered flexible task force organization
Integration of self-propelled artillery with armored maneuver elements
Reconnaissance battalion provides deep reconnaissance capability
known_issues: Division too large and unwieldy for effective control (would be reorganized 1943)
Tank distribution across two regiments dispersed firepower
M3 Lee/Grant tanks inferior to German Panzer IV in Tunisia
Inexperienced crews and commanders in first combat operations
Supply and maintenance units struggled with North African conditions
Dispersal of Combat Commands by higher headquarters reduced division effectiveness
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division still adapting to North African conditions in December 1942. Issues with sand filters, water supply, navigation, and maintenance in austere environment. Medjez el Bab disaster (10-11 December) highlighted vulnerability to mud and weather in rainy season.

scenario_suitability: First American tank vs. tank combat actions
special_rules: Green Unit: -1 to all combat rolls in first three scenarios
Dispersed Organization: Combat Commands may be separated by up to 50km
Supply Strain: Roll for supply shortage on any turn distance > 200km from Oran
Maintenance Issues: 15% of tanks non-operational at start of each scenario
Learning Curve: Experience level improves to Regular after Kasserine Pass
